journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part K: Journal of Multi-body Dynamics

title-group.article-title: Stochastic dynamics and fatigue analysis of large-scale mechanical models using multilevel substructuring

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Aristotle University, Greece

author-notes.corresp: S Natsiavas, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Aristotle University, 54 124 Thessaloniki, Greece. Email: natsiava@auth.gr

abstract.p: An efficient methodology is presented for predicting dynamic response and fatigue life of large-scale nonlinear mechanical models, subjected to random excitation. The methodology developed is based on a combination of techniques leading to a fast and accurate determination of the dynamic response with a method related to an efficient prediction of fatigue life. Specifically, the first step involves application of an appropriate coordinate transformation, causing a drastic reduction in the degrees of freedom. This opens the way to the application of another numerical method, leading to direct determination of periodic steady-state response of nonlinear systems under periodic forcing. This approach provides a solid foundation for the subsequent application of a rainflow stress cycle counting method, leading to prediction of fatigue failure. The computational accuracy and effectiveness of the methodology is illustrated by a quite involved example model, representing a city bus subjected to road excitation. Typical results are presented for both the stochastic response and the fatigue life by considering excitation arising from selected road profiles with known statistical properties. Special attention is paid to assessing the effect of the nonlinearity, by considering profiles of different quality. Moreover, a critical comparison is performed on results referring to the expected fatigue lifetime, obtained by applying methods in both the frequency and the time domain. In this way, the applicability of classical spectral methods in nonlinear models is also investigated.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Nowadays, it is frequently necessary to predict the dynamic response and the fatigue life of complex multibody mechanical systems in a fast and reliable manner. For instance, this is a major issue in the various design stages of ground vehicles, aircraft, aerospace vehicles, wind turbines, ships and offshore structures. In the present work, a general class of models is examined, involving three main levels of complexity. The first source of complexity is associated with the large order of the equations of motion, which result after application of the finite element method to the structure examined. Second, the excitation history is not known exactly. Instead, sufficient information about its statistical properties is available, leading to the need to apply stochastic approaches. Finally, the system properties or the level of the excitation result in a significant activation of nonlinear action. All these factors cause serious difficulties in the efforts to predict the response of modern mechanical systems, even when powerful computer systems are available.

The development of any efficient method for predicting the service life of a complex structure is based on the prior application of appropriate numerical methods, leading to accurate and fast determination of its dynamic response. The latter task has become more tractable and feasible, especially in the last three decades, due to significant evolution in the areas of computer hardware and software. Originally, the emphasis was put on large-scale systems possessing linear characteristics.1,2 Traditionally, it is more convenient to attack and solve these problems by applying methods founded in the frequency domain. More recently, appropriate techniques have also been applied in capturing the response of large-scale systems involving nonlinear action.3,4 The profits from the application of such methods are substantial, especially when the response has to be obtained in an iterative manner. This is the case corresponding to systems subjected to stochastic excitation or involving nonlinear characteristics, where the direct problem has to be solved many times before a desired level of numerical convergence is achieved.5

In particular, development and application of methods predicting high-cycle fatigue failure in metallic structures in a fast and reliable manner has been in the epicenter of research efforts for a long time. For a constant amplitude loading, experimental information obtained from classical S–N fatigue curves, can be directly utilized.6 For variable amplitude forcing, the classical Palmgren–Miner linear damage accumulation law is usually applied in conjunction with an appropriate stress cycle counting method and utilization of information extracted from S–N curves. For the special case of mechanical systems with linear characteristics, a plethora of methods is available.7–14 However, the situation is more complicated when the system examined has a large dimension and involves nonlinearities. Due to the large practical significance of this problem, several attempts have already been recorded in this area, but many questions of fundamental importance are still open.15,16

The main objective of the present work is twofold. First, the attention is focused on developing an appropriate method for an efficient determination of the response of large-scale and nonlinear mechanical systems under random excitation. Then, the emphasis is shifted on improving and expediting the calculations related to prediction of their service life. Usually, reliable models result by applyig finite element techniques. Among other benefits, the development of such models assists the efforts of reducing the number of costly experimental trials or extracting more useful information by providing useful guidance in setting the experiments. Ηowever, in such cases, the total volume of the data produced by the calculations needed is frequently quite excessive, while the available computing time is usually relatively short. Therefore, this requires the establishment of suitable methods, leading to accurate and fast determination of the dynamic response of complex dynamical models under representative operational conditions. In addition, the ability to do this provides the basis for performing many other direct or indirect analyses, like the prediction of fatigue failure. Consequently, the ultimate objective of this work is to present a complete and systematic methodology, which will be useful for performing fatigue studies of complex mechanical models, by appropriately employing and combining effective numerical techniques developed in earlier studies for the first time.4,17 In fact, this is the novelty of the present work.

First, the complexity associated with the excessive number of degrees of freedom is alleviated considerably by the application of an appropriate coordinate reduction procedure.4 The basic idea is to first reduce the numerical dimension of the system examined, so that a comprehensive and accurate study of the dynamics can be performed within a specified forcing frequency range. This in turn allows the subsequent application of another numerical technique, causing a direct determination of response spectra of the system. In particular, a method developed recently for obtaining periodic steady-state response of a periodically excited nonlinear system is applied, leading to an additional reduction in the calculations needed in predicting the fatigue life of a structure.17 The validity and effectiveness of the new methodology is illustrated by presenting numerical results for an involved finite element model of a city bus, subjected to excitation resulting from typical urban road irregularities. Determination of the response leads to information, which is then utilized for predicting fatigue failure. Special emphasis is put in examining the effect of the nonlinearities, with particular attention focused in the time savings arising from application of the new methodology. In addition, a critical comparison is performed for results obtained in the frequency and in the time domain.

This article is organized as follows. First, the class of mechanical models examined is presented in the following section, while the theoretical foundation for performing the fatigue analysis is presented in the third section. The fourth section is devoted to summarizing the main features of a method leading to an efficient prediction of the dynamic response and the fatigue life of the class of systems considered. A representative set of numerical results is presented in the fifth section. Namely, stochastic response of a city bus model is investigated first. Then, results related to prediction of its fatigue lifetime are also presented. Finally, the most important conclusions of the present study are summarized in the last section.

sec.title: Class of mechanical models – coordinate reduction
sec.p: The prediction of the response of mechanical systems involving structural components with complicated geometry makes necessary the application of the finite element method. Consequently, the resulting models possess a large number of degrees of freedom. In addition, the system properties or the level of the forcing may cause significant activation of nonlinear effects. Therefore, the set of equations of motion can be cast in the matrix form (1)M∧x··¯+C∧x·¯+K∧x¯+p∧¯(x¯,x·¯)=f∧¯(t) where vector x¯(t) includes the unknowns, while the matrices M∧, C∧ and K∧ are constant and related to inertia, damping and restoring forces of the system, respectively. Moreover, vectors p∧¯(x¯,x·¯) and f∧¯(t) include nonlinear and forcing terms, respectively. An additional factor of complexity, characterizing the class of systems examined, is that this forcing may not be known as an explicit function of time. That is, the loading is stochastic and as a consequence only its essential statistical properties are available, instead.

The presence of the nonlinear terms and the stochastic nature of the loading imply the need for performing numerical iterations in determining the dynamic response. Taking into account the large dimension of the equations of motion (1), this task is associated with a huge amount of computing time and an excessive volume of data, which cannot be accommodated effectively even when utilizing the large computational power of modern computing systems. However, a significant relief of this numerical burden can be achieved by applying appropriate methods, leading to a drastic reduction in the original number of degrees of freedom.

The coordinate reduction method applied in this work has been presented in detail in a previous work.4 In brief, this method is a generalization of the classical Craig–Bampton method.1 Namely, instead of working with the complete mass and stiffness matrices, their sparsity pattern is used as a guide in first splitting them into a number of suitably selected mathematical substructures.2 Then, for a given level of forcing frequencies and a desired level of numerical accuracy, a Ritz coordinate transformation with form (2)x¯i(t)=Tiq¯i(t) is applied to each substructure, where the columns of matrix Ti are fixed interface normal modes complemented by static correction modes.1 Since these individual transformations are performed on many small dimensional systems, a drastic reduction in the computation time and data tranfer is achieved. Moreover, after reassembling all the substructures through a multi-level process, the equations of motion of the multiple component system are obtained eventually in the form (3)Mq··¯+Cq·¯+Kq¯+p¯(q¯,q·¯)=f¯(t) where the vector of the unknowns appears in the form (4)q¯=(η¯x¯B)

The part x¯B includes all the degrees of freedom associated with local nonlinear and damping action, in order to preserve the exact nonlinear and damping characteristics. Therefore, the method applied is most effective for systems involving a relatively small number of degrees of freedom associated with isolated viscous damping or nonlinear forces. This, however, is very common in engineering applications. In addition, the form of the transformed stiffness and mass matrices is very convenient. For instance, the transformed stiffness matrix K appears in the form (5)K=[Λ00KB,B] where the upper part Λ of the transformed stiffness matrix K is diagonal. Likewise, the corresponding upper part of the mass matrix M is occupied by identity matrices. However, the off diagonal blocks between coupled substructures are nonzero.2,4

The only part of the stiffness and mass matrix that is densely populated is that represented by KB,B and MB,B, respectively, corresponding to the set x¯B. The dimension of these submatrices is usually much smaller than that of vector q¯, which in turn is much smaller than the dimension of vector x¯ in the original system (1). This provides the key to perform an efficient prediction of the fatigue life of large-scale mechanical models with nonlinear properties. These two important issues are explained in the following two sections.

sec.title: Fatigue analysis
sec.p: Estimation of damage accumulation due to fatigue of a metallic structure is of vital importance in the design of many modern mechanical systems. When the loading applied has constant amplitude (i.e. when it is harmonic or possibly periodic), the necessary information can be obtained from the classical S–N curves. These curves provide the number of cycles Nf required to cause fatigue failure at a point under a uni-axial stress state with zero mean and range Sr through the formula (6)Nf(Sr)=KSr-m

The positive constants K and m are determined by curve fitting experimental data obtained for simple specimens and depend on the material properties and the geometrical shape of the test specimen. For non-zero mean stress, there exist simple ways (like the Goodman correction or the Gerber formula) leading to a modification of the fatigue estimate resulting from equation (6). However, for variable amplitude loading, the process becomes more involved. Specifically, for a general loading history, the equivalent number of cycles at each stress range must first be identified by applying a suitable technique. Among the many techniques available, the rainflow cycle counting method is very popular.6 This method is frequently used in conjunction with the Palmgren–Miner linear damage accumulation law. According to this law, the damage accumulation at a point is evaluated from (7)D=∑i=1N1Nf(Sr,i) where N is the total number of stress ranges identified in the stress time history, while Nf(Sr,i) is the number of cycles causing fatigue at the stress range Sr,i. The last two quantities are related through equation (6). Then, the expected value of the fatigue damage accumulation can be determined from D¯=E[D]=∫0∞n(Sr)Nf(Sr)dSr

If p(Sr) is the probability density function of the stress range, then the quantity n(Sr)=TE[P]p(Sr)dSr represents the number of cycles at stress ranges within the interval [Sr,Sr+dSr], where E[P] is the expected number of cycles per unit time and T is the time period of observation. Eventually, through application of equation (6), the following result is reached for the mean value of the fatigue damage accumulation (8)D¯=TKE[P]∫0∞Srmp(Sr)dSr

In the setting presented so far, the time for failure due to fatigue is a random variable. Its expected value, say TL, is determined by substituting D¯=1 in the last expression. In this way, the fatigue lifetime is evaluated from (9)TL=KE[P]∫0∞Srmp(Sr)dSr

In the general case, fatigue lifetime is evaluated by taking into account experimental data or the outcome of extensive numerical simulation in the time domain, in conjunction with a stress cycle counting method. Based on such information, a histogram of the stress range distribution is first created. Then, the probability density function of the stress range is determined in the form (10)p(Sr,i)=niNΔSr,i where ni represents the histogram counts within the stress range ΔSr,i.16

In the special case where the system examined is linear and the excitation is a stationary Gaussian stochastic process, the overall response is also a stationary Gaussian stochastic process. Then, there exist several approximate analytical techniques yielding a sufficiently accurate estimate for the stochastic fatigue lifetime. Most of these techniques are empirical spectral methods and require information related to the autospectral density function of the stochastic process representing the critical stress.6 In brief, if the random process {X(t)} represents the stress history at a critical point of a structure, the spectral methods employ formulas based on certain spectral moments of the stress power spectral density function, say SXX(ω). These spectral parameters are defined by (11)λm=2∫0∞ωmSXX(ω)dω

If, in addition, the stress examined is a narrow band stochastic process, a closed-form formula is available for the fatigue lifetime, based on a Rayleigh distribution of the stress range. Then, the number of stress cycles per second is assumed to be equal to the expected number of peaks per second, which in turn is equal to the expected number of upcrossings of the mean stress value per second. For a stationary Gaussian loading, these parameters are expressed in terms of the spectral parameters in the form (12)E[P]=NP=12πλ4λ2andN0=12πλ2λ0 respectively. For a non-narrow band process, several spectral methods are also available.7–10 Among them, Dirlik’s formula provides an empirical expression for the probability density function of the stress range.10 This formula is approximate but it appears in a convenient closed form, depending on the spectral parameters λ0, λ1, λ2 and λ4. Based on their definition, expressed by equation (11), it is easy to show that (13)λ0=σX2,λ2=σX·2andλ4=σX··2 which means that these parameters represent the variance of the stochastic processes {X(t)}, {X·(t)} and {X··(t)}, respectively. Finally, certain modifications are necessary for non-Gaussian stress processes, involving evaluation of higher order statistical moments, like the skewness and the kurtosis of the stress process.11,12 Moreover, several criteria are also available for cases where the critical stress state is multi-axial.13,14

sec.title: Prediction of dynamic response and fatigue life
sec.p: The elements of vector f¯(t) in the equations of motion (5) represent action arising from external forcing. In many applications, this vector is not available as a known function of time. Instead, only some statistical information is available for it. For instance, the excitation of ground vehicles results mostly by continuously distributed irregularities of the road profile, which are characterized by random fields. These fields are real-valued, zero mean, stationary and Gaussian. Therefore, for their complete statistical description it is sufficient to specify their second order moment only. Here, this requirement is fulfilled by assuming that the road irregularities possess a known single-sided power spectral density, say Sg(Ω), where Ω=2π/λ is a spatial frequency, corresponding to a harmonic irregularity with wavelength λ. According to previous investigations on the subject, the geometrical profile of typical roads fits the following simple analytical form (14)Sg(Ω)={Sg(Ω0)(Ω/Ω0)-n1, if Ω≤Ω0Sg(Ω0)(Ω/Ω0)-n2, if Ω≥Ω0 where Ω0=1/2π is a reference spatial frequency, while the value Sg(Ω0) provides a measure for the roughness of the road profile.18 Knowledge of the function Sg(Ω) is necessary for evaluating the autospectral density function matrix SFF(ω) corresponding to the stochastic forcing f¯(t). In these calculations, the spatial frequency Ω is converted to a temporal frequency ω=Ωv0, where v0 represents the constant horizontal speed of the vehicle.

For the special case of a model with linear properties, knowledge of the power spectral density function matrix of the forcing SFF(ω) permits a direct evaluation of the autospectral density function matrix of the response, say SXX(ω), through the well-known formula (15)SXX(ω)=H(ω)SFF(ω)HT*(ω) where H(ω) is the harmonic transfer function matrix of the structural system.5,6 This approach is convenient since there is no need to consider specific time histories. However, for models involving nonlinearities, the frequency domain analysis is no longer valid and an analytical formulation for the second moment response characteristics is not available.19 For such cases, the probabilistic characteristics of the response are evaluated by using Monte-Carlo simulations, in conjunction with appropriate numerical integration methodologies.

More specifically, for nonlinear models, samples of the elements of the forcing vector are generated by using the spectral representation method.5 In particular, for a ground vehicle traveling with a constant horizontal speed v0 over a road, the forcing resulting from the road irregularities can be simulated by the following finite Fourier series (16)xg(t)=∑n=1Nsnsin(nω0t+φn)

In the last formula, the amplitudes of the excitation harmonics are evaluated from the road spectra in the form sn=2Sg(nΔΩ)ΔΩ, where ΔΩ=2π/L and L is the length of the road segment, while the value of the fundamental temporal frequency ω0 is determined from ω0=2πv0/L. Finally, the phases φn are treated as random variables, following a uniform distribution in the interval [0,2π).

Obviously, the forcing function expressed by equation (16) is periodic, with fundamental period depending on the selected level of discretization of the forcing spectrum. Therefore, a central idea of this study is to employ a method presented in a recent publication, by which one can determine directly the steady-state response of a nonlinear system to periodic excitation.17 This facilitates greatly the performance of the Monte-Carlo simulations needed for extracting the necessary statistical properties of the response, due to a sequence of random forcing functions expressed by equation (16), by avoiding the large cost associated with performing lengthy direct integration of the equations of motion through the transient vibration part. For this purpose, the velocity vector v¯=q·¯ is first introduced. Then, the reduced set of equations of motion (3) is rewritten in the first order form (17)u·¯=h¯(u¯,t) with u¯=(x¯v¯)andh¯(u¯,t)=(v¯M-1[f¯(t)-Cv¯-Kx¯-p¯(x¯,v¯)])
In the special cases where the excitation is periodic, with period T, that is f¯(t+T)=f¯(t) the system may also reach a periodic steady state, with (18)u¯(t+T)=u¯(t)
Such motions are determined here in a direct and systematic manner, by applying a shooting method (for more details, see Theodosiou et al.17).

In summary, the method developed starts by selecting a sequence of random excitations in the periodic form expressed by equation (16). The fundamental temporal frequency ω0 and the number of harmonic terms are chosen based on pre-specified requirements on the minimum frequency step and the total frequency range of interest, respectively, while the randomness of these excitations is related to the selection of the phases φn. Then, the method described above is applied for each of these forcing functions, leading directly to the corresponding steady-state response. Finally, the process is completed through repeated selection of new forcing samples and performing the statistics up until sufficient numerical convergence is achieved in the desired response quantities.

The method developed exploits fully another substantial advantage, related to the fact that the exact statistics of the response can be performed directly in the time domain, since the exact response histories are available for every forcing function. Specifically, for a given response time signal, it is straightforward to count quantities like the number of peaks, the number of upcrossings of the mean value as well the number of the rainflow cycles of the signal per second. Moreover, besides the mean value and the standard deviation, one can easily evaluate the skewness and the kurtosis of the signal. For a Gaussian process, it is known that the last two quantities take the values 0 and 3, respectively.15,16 Therefore, any deviation from these values signifies a departure from Gaussianity. For instance, this is the case when the system examined involves nonlinearities. In such a case, even when the forcing is Gaussian, the response is in general non-Gaussian.5,6

The new method leads to significant computational advantages, when compared to classical Monte-Carlo methods based on averaging results obtained by direct integration of the equations of motion. Specifically, this method is much less time consuming, since there is no need to integrate through the original transient part of the dynamic response. Moreover, the results obtained by this method are equally accurate since the statistics are also performed in the time domain.

sec.title: Numerical results
sec.p: A set of typical numerical results are presented in this section. First, the attention is focussed on presenting the basic ingredients of an involved finite element model of a complete city bus. Then, results related to dynamic response of this model under random forcing are included in the second subsection. Finally, in the third subsection the emphasis is placed on investigating fatigue characteristics of the bus model. Special attention is paid to illustrating the accuracy and effectiveness of the methodology developed.

sec.title: Example mechanical model
sec.p:
The complete multibody mechanical model of a low floor urban bus with two axles, examined in this section, is shown in Figure 1(a). Besides modeling the bus superstructure and chassis frame, several important subsystems, like the front and rear suspension (shown in Figure 1(b)), were also considered. In addition, the seat-passenger subsystems as well as the wheel subsystems were represented by appropriate sets of discrete mass, stiffness and damping elements. As a result of this discretization, a model possessing about 1.4 million degrees of freedom was obtained. More details about the bus model examined can be found in an earlier study.18 Figure 1.
(a) Complete bus model, (b) rear suspension substructure.

In the example system, its nonlinearities appear at the suspension subsystems only. For instance, the stiffness properties of all the suspension units were modeled according to the graphs included in Figure 2(a). In this case, the nonlinearity is caused by the presence of suspension bump and rebound stops. Moreover, the main dampers of the front suspension possess linear characteristics, while the force developed in the main dampers of the rear suspension exhibits the form shown in Figure 2(b). In the latter case, the rebound (extension) equivalent damping coefficients are much higher than the corresponding jounce (compression) damping coefficients, in accordance to common practice in automotive engineering.20 Moreover, the equivalent damping coefficients are lower at higher velocities. Figure 2.
(a) Force–displacement characteristics of the main suspension springs, (b) force–velocity relation in the rear suspension dampers.

The localized nature of the system nonlinearities makes efficient the application of the special techniques described in the second and fourth section, leading to a drastic reduction in the number of degrees of freedom and direct determination of periodic steady-state motions. Specifically, since the emphasis of the present study is put on ride response of the bus, the reduced model is required to exhibit sufficient accuracy in the frequency range between 0 and 30 Hz.18,20 As a result, the reduced model possesses 296 degrees of freedom only. This is much smaller than the dimension of the original system and allows a much faster determination of its response, without sacrificing numerical accuracy. As a first evidence of this, in Figure 3 are presented the undamped natural frequencies of the linearized bus models corresponding to the original and the reduced model in the frequency range 0–100 Hz. Both of these models resulted by linearizing the equations of motion around the static equilibrium position of the bus. Clearly, the agreement obtained between the predictions of these models within the prespecified frequency range is satisfactory. On the other hand, some deviations become apparent for frequency values outside this range. Figure 3.
Comparison of the natural frequencies of the bus model in the frequency range 0–100 Hz.

sec.title: Results on dynamic response to stochastic excitation
sec.p: Some selected numerical results referring to dynamic response of the example model to random excitation are presented in this subsection. These results were obtained by applying typical road excitation to the bus model described in the previous subsection. In all calculations, it was assumed that the bus moves on a straight path with a constant horizontal speed v0 = 50 km/h. Also, all the subsequent results were obtained for different quality road profiles. More specifically, these profiles were generated from equations (14) and (16), with exponents n1 = 2 and n2 = 1.5. In addition, for good quality (class B) and poor quality (class D) road profiles, the amplitude Sg(Ω0) in equation (14) was selected to be equal to 16 × 10−6 m2/cycle/m and 256 × 10−6 m2/cycle/m, respectively.

At the beginning, some preliminary numerical results are presented, illustrating the validity and effectiveness of the methodology. Specifically, in Figure 4 is shown a comparison of the time histories obtained for the deformation of the main spring in the rear right suspension, over a forcing period, by running direct integration of the equations of motion of the full and the reduced bus models. In particular, in Figure 4(a) is shown the first response period, while the results in Figure 4(b) refer to a response period captured at a later time, where the bus response has reached periodic steady-state conditions, under a specific periodic loading, belonging to class B road profiles. In both cases, the integration of the equations of motion started from zero initial conditions. Figure 4.
Deformation history of the rear right suspension spring obtained by the full and the reduced bus model: (a) during the first forcing period, (b) at steady-state conditions.

Direct comparison of the results depicted in Figure 4 demonstrates that the predictions obtained by the complete and the reduced model are virtually indistinguishable. This illustrates the accuracy of the reduced model. On the other hand, there is a considerable difference in the corresponding computing times. Specifically, it took 180 h and 12 min for the complete model and only 31 min for the reduced model to finish the calculations. Both of these observations reinforce the expectation for the great numerical efficiency of the method applied.

After establishing the accuracy and effectiveness of the methodology, the emphasis was put on collecting and presenting results related to response of the system under random excitation. Specifically, all the results presented next were obtained by employing the reduced bus model and refer to a point of the rear suspension, marked by A in Figure 1(b), where the fatigue calculations are performed in the following subsection.

First, in Figure 5 are presented results for the vertical displacement obtained at point A of the rear suspension, by considering the linearized bus model (obtained by using the stiffness and damping coefficients at the origin of Figure 2) and excitation caused by quality B and D road profiles. The first set of them, shown in Figure 5(a), refers to the power spectral density functions of the displacement process. According to common vehicle engineering practice, the main attention is put within the forcing frequency interval 0–30 Hz.20 Likewise, in Figure 5(b) are included the corresponding cumulative root mean square (rms) values. Figure 5.
Response diagrams obtained for the vertical displacement at point A of the rear suspension of the linearized bus model: (a) power spectral density, (b) cumulative root mean square function.

Based on the results depicted in Figure 5(a), it is apparent that the response spectra obtained have an identical form, as expected from relations (16) and (17). The only difference is in the amplitude of the forcing. In particular, the ratio of the forcing amplitudes is SgD(Ω0)/SgB(Ω0) = 256/16 = 16, leading to a 16 times bigger amplitude of SXXD(ω) with respect to SXXB(ω), while the corresponding rms values are 4 times bigger, throughout the frequency range examined. Moreover, the energy of the displacement signal is concentrated in the low frequency range. This is reflected by the results of Figure 5(b), which demonstrate that the corresponding cumulative rms value remains virtually constant for frequency values bigger than about 11 Hz.

The two main peaks in Figure 5(a) were found to have a strong correlation with two linear mode shapes of the mechanical model examined, shown in Figure 6. The corresponding natural frequencies are 1.95 and 10.42 Hz. Both of them are global modes, which can easily be excited by the selected road forcing. In particular, the first of them is dominated by an almost rigid body motion of the bus body, while most of the deformation is located in the main springs of the front and rear suspensions. On the contrary, the second mode involves significant bending deformation of the bus body. Figure 6.
Linear mode shape of the bus at: (a) 1.95 Hz and (b) 10.42 Hz.

In the following sequence of results, the attention is shifted to identifying effects caused by the activation of the model nonlinearities. In particular, in Figures 7 and 8 are included diagrams obtained for the vertical acceleration at the same point of the bus rear suspension. These results are similar in nature to those presented in Figure 5 and were obtained for class B and D road profiles, respectively. Figure 7.
(a) Power spectral density and (b) cumulative root mean square function, obtained for the vertical acceleration at point A of the rear suspension of the nonlinear bus model under loading caused by class B road profiles. Figure 8.
(a) Power spectral density and (b) cumulative root mean square function, obtained for the vertical acceleration at point A of the rear suspension of the nonlinear bus model under loading caused by class D road profiles.

First, the results of Figure 7(a) demonstrate the existence of deviations between the predictions of the nonlinear and the linearized bus model. These differences are noticeable near the two peaks observed in the power spectral density of the linearized model. More specifically, these resonance peaks are shifted to higher frequency values, in accordance with the stiffening characteristics of the suspension springs (Figure 2(a)). In addition, more resonances appear around these two frequency spots in the nonlinear model, most probably due to activation of nonlinear superharmonic action.3,17 Finally, the results of Figure 7(b) reveal that most of the energy in the signals examined is confined within the frequency range 2–11 Hz, again. Also, the signal obtained from the linear model appears to contain a larger amount of response energy. On the other hand, comparison with the corresponding results presented in Figure 5 for the displacement illustrates that the acceleration signal energy is concentrated into the higher part of the frequency range examined, as expected.

Qualitatively similar results are also presented in Figure 8, obtained from random excitation caused by class D quality road profiles. First, direct comparison of the results in Figure 8(a) indicates that, besides the higher response amplitudes, there appear more significant deviations between the predictions of the nonlinear and the linearized model, throughout the frequency range examined. Also, more resonances and more noticeable frequency shifting are obvious for the nonlinear model. All these observations are reasonable,3 since the much larger amplitude of the irregularities corresponding to class D road profiles cause a stronger activation of the system nonlinearities. Finally, based on the results of Figure 8(b), it appears that the energy of the acceleration signal remains also between 2 and 11 Hz mostly, while the total energy content of the signal obtained for the nonlinear model is still smaller but closer to that predicted by the linearized model.

sec.title: Results on prediction of fatigue lifetime
sec.p: The numerical results presented in this subsection are related to an efficient numerical estimation of fatigue lifetime of the example bus model. Emphasis is placed in demonstrating the effectiveness of the overall methodology developed in the present study. Moreover, an effort is made to illustrate the differences appearing in the prediction of the fatigue lifetime when using a classical spectral method for the case of the nonlinear model, instead of the more appropriate time domain approach.

For the special case of a linear model, knowledge of the road profile power spectral density and the vehicle velocity permits evaluation of the power spectral density of the stationary vehicle response through equation (15). This in turn permits the calculation of the corresponding spectral parameters through equation (11), allowing a subsequent fatigue life evaluation by employing any of the spectral methods known. In particular, among all the possible methods, Dirlik’s method was selected as the most appropriate for the purposes of the present study. On the other hand, when the model examined is nonlinear, the frequency domain analysis looses its theoretical foundation. For such cases, the probabilistic characteristics of the response are usually evaluated by performing Monte-Carlo simulations, in conjunction with appropriate direct integration of the equations of motion.5 A similar approach is adopted in this study. However, instead of direct integration, the method described in the section ‘Prediction of dynamic response and fatigue life’ for directly predicting periodic steady-state response is employed.

A decisive factor in fatigue lifetime prediction is the selection of a proper stress criterion. Based on preliminary calculations, the maximum level of stresses for the loading examined were found to occur close to point A of the rear suspension (Figure 1(b)). In Figure 9 is presented the power spectral density function obtained at point A of the linearized bus model for the local σxx, σyy and σxy stresses. The corresponding σmax stress is also shown together. Clearly, the values of σyy and σmax are virtually coincident and much higher than the values of the other stresses. This reflects the fact that the local stress σyy is dominant at the selected point. For this reason, it was chosen as the critical stress for the subsequent fatigue calculations. Figure 9.
Power spectral density of the local σxx, σyy, σxy and σmax stresses, developed at point A of the rear suspension of the linearized bus model.

The final set of figures illustrates differences in the predictions of some key quantities, based on the response of the linearized and the nonlinear bus model. In particular, the results of Figure 10 were obtained by considering the local σyy stress resulting at point A due to excitation caused by road profiles of class B quality. First, two typical time histories are shown in Figure 10(a), while the corresponding power spectral density functions are shown in Figure 10(b). Finally, Figure 10(c) shows the probability density function obtained for the corresponding stress range by applying the rainflow cycle counting method, while in Figure 10(d) are shown similar results, evaluated by Dirlik’s method. Figure 10.
Predictions of the linearized and the nonlinear bus model for the local σyy stress at point A of the rear suspension resulting by class B roads: (a) time histories, (b) power spectral density functions, (c) probability density function of the stress range by the rainflow cycle counting method and (d) probability density function by Dirlik’s method.

Critical comparison of the results presented in Figure 10(a) and (b) demonstrates the appearance of observable differences in both the time histories and the power spectral densities predicted by the linear and the nonlinear model. Also, these differences are then reflected in the probability density functions of the stress range, included in Figure 10(c) and (d). Moreover, it is worth noticing that there exist important differences in the probability density functions obtained by the rainflow cycle counting and by Dirlik’s method in both the low and the high stress range values. These differences are due to the fact that the probability density function obtained by Dirlik’s method is a combination of an exponential and two Rayleigh distributions and dies quickly as the stress range increases.10 On the contrary, the probability density functions determined by the rainflow cycle counting method present noticeable values even for larger values of the stress range.

Likewise, in Figure 11 are depicted similar results, obtained by considering excitation caused by road profiles characterized by class D quality. First, direct comparison with the results of Figure 10 illustrates that the differences in the response caused by increasing the forcing intensity become more pronounced. Specifically, contrary to the predictions of the linear theory, the form of the power spectral density function changes with the forcing amplitude in a non-uniform manner over the frequency range examined. Moreover, the peaks of the nonlinear model appear at higher frequencies. Finally, comparison of the results obtained for the nonlinear and the linearized model indicates that the effect of the bus nonlinearities are significant. For instance, the probability density function obtained by the rainflow cycle counting method for the nonlinear model presents significantly higher values in the area of large stress ranges than those determined for the linear model (Figure 11(c)) and those obtained by Dirlik’s method (Figure 11(d)). This will be one of the main reasons for the considerably different predictions that will result for the estimated fatigue lifetime. Figure 11.
Predictions of the linearized and the nonlinear bus model for the local σyy stress at point A of the rear suspension resulting by class D roads: (a) time histories, (b) power spectral density functions, (c) probability density function of the stress range by the rainflow cycle counting method and (d) probability density function by Dirlik’s method.

The final set of results, included in Tables 1 to 4, refers to a critical comparison of response quantities related to prediction of fatigue lifetime. This particular set of results was obtained by using the numerical values m = 3.303 and K = 1.01 × 1025 for the constant parameters in equation (6) and the comparison is performed in two different directions. In the first, the emphasis is put in investigating the effect of the system nonlinearities. For instance, the results included in Tables 1 and 3 were obtained by employing the linearized bus model, while in Tables 2 and 4 are presented similar results, determined by utilizing the nonlinear model. In the second level of comparison, the efforts concentrate in examining results obtained in the frequency and in the time domain. In particular, the results in the frequency domain (FDA) were obtained by first evaluating the power spectral density of the response to a given random loading. Then, the corresponding spectral parameters were determined through equation (11), while the rest of the quantities were evaluated by using appropriate formulas presented in the third section. On the other hand, the results determined by application of the time domain analysis (TDA) were obtained by performing the statistics over the specific response time histories, captured by repeated application of periodic random loading, up until sufficient numerical convergence was achieved. Table 1.
Characteristic statistical values for the local σyy stress at point A of the linear bus model.

TDA TDA FDA TDA TDA

Class D −32.15 13.64 13.64 0.042 3.05

Class A 5.50 5.02 28.02 27.96 2.16e8 2.33e8
Class B 5.51 5.02 28.01 27.96 2.08e7 2.79e7
Class C 5.51 5.02 28.02 27.97 3.48e6 4.12e6
Class D 5.51 5.02 28.04 27.97 6.31e5 9.23e5
Table 4.
Statistical quantities related to prediction of fatigue lifetime (nonlinear bus model).
Road quality N0 (Hz) NP (Hz) Rainflow (s) Dirlik (s)
TDA FDA TDA FDA TDA FDA
Class A 4.94 4.89 20.91 20.88 1.99e8 2.19e8
Class B 4.96 4.89 20.92 20.89 5.22e6 9.41e6
Class C 5.09 4.91 20.95 20.89 8.68e4 35.21e4
Class D 5.18 4.95 21.12 20.91 9.62e3 40.37e3

The first set of results refers to statistics of the response and are included in Tables 1 and 2. These results were obtained for the linear and the nonlinear bus model, respectively. Specifically, the mean, the standard deviation, the skewness and the kurtosis values were computed for the local σyy stress obtained at point A of the bus rear suspension, for four different road qualities (from class A to class D), indicated in the first column. All these statistical quantities were computed in the time domain. For the standard deviation, in particular, the calculations were also performed in the frequency domain, by employing the first of equations (13).

From the results presented in these two tables, the following conclusions can be drawn. First, the standard deviation values computed by the frequency domain analysis are virtually coincident with the corresponding values obtained by the time domain analysis, for both the linear and the nonlinear model. Moreover, the values of the skewness and the kurtosis computed from the linear model (Table 1), stay reasonably close to zero and three, respectively, which means that the stress response remains essentially Gaussian. However, in Table 2, significant deviations from these values are observed, despite the fact that the loading applied is Gaussian. This deviation is mostly due to the nonlinear action arising in the model and increases as the forcing intensity is increased. Furthermore, direct comparison reveals that there appear significant differences in both the mean and the standard deviation values predicted by the nonlinear linearized and the linearized models. Finally, these differences are amplified as the forcing amplitude is increased. These differences are reflected in the fatigue lifetime predictions, presented in the sequel.

Next, some additional results are presented in Tables 3 and 4, related more closely to fatigue lifetime predictions, based on the values of the local σyy stress obtained at point A of the bus rear suspension. Again, these results were obtained by considering the linearized and the nonlinear bus model, respectively. The first column indicates the quality of the road profiles considered. Then, in the second and third column are included results related to the number of upcrossings of the mean value per second, obtained in the frequency and the time domain, respectively. Similar results are also included in the fourth and fifth column for the number of peaks per second. Finally, the last two columns present results referring to predictions of the fatigue lifetime.

In the frequency domain, the number of upcrossings and the number of peaks per second were obtained by employing equation (12). Then, the fatigue lifetime was obtained by applying Dirlik’s spectral method. Namely, the corresponding probability density function of the stress range was evaluated from a closed-form expression,10 while the lifetime was subsequently determined from equation (9). In the time domain, the number of upcrossings and the number of peaks per second were obtained by taking the appropriate statistics on the located time signals directly. Moreover, the probability density function of the stress range was evaluated through the application of the rainflow cycle counting method in conjunction with equation (10) and the lifetime was subsequently determined from equation (9).

First, critical comparison of the results of Table 3 leads to the following conclusions. The predictions of the linear frequency domain method for the number of upcrossings and the number of peaks per second do not depend on the excitation level. This is almost true even for the predictions of the time domain analysis, which gives slightly higher values in both cases. Furthermore, comparison of the values for the number of upcrossings per second with the number of peaks per second, in each forcing case, reveals that the excitation applied can be characterized as broadband. On the other hand, the fatigue life is found to be reduced with an increase in the intensity of the excitation, as expected. Moreover, Dirlik’s method predicts a bit higher service life. However, the predictions of Dirlik’s method stay reasonably close to the predictions of the rainflow cycle counting method for all the cases examined.

The final set of results, presented in Table 4, was obtained by considering the nonlinear bus model. Here, the predictions of the frequency domain method referring to the number of upcrossings and the number of peaks per second do depend on the excitation level. However, this dependence is weak, which is also the case for the corresponding predictions of the time domain analysis. On the other hand, the differences between the fatigue lifetime predictions of the analysis performed in the frequency and in the time domain are more significant. In particular, application of the spectral method yields much longer fatigue life time than the more accurate rainflow cycle counting method, for the same level of forcing. Such differences are expected, because even the applicability of Dirlik’s method is questionable in this case, since the stress process examined is no longer Gaussian, as indicated by the results in the last two columns of Table 2. Moreover, direct comparison with the corresponding values in Table 3 reveals that the fatigue lifetime predicted by the nonlinear model can be considerably smaller than that predicted by the linearized model. Finally, these differences seem to increase with the forcing intensity, due probably to the heavier activation of the nonlinearity of the suspension main springs under stronger external forcing (Figure 2(a)). These observations illustrate that caution should be exercised when employing linearized models or applying classical spectral (frequency domain) approaches to nonlinear models, since this may lead to highly non-conservative predictions of the fatigue life time of a structure.

sec.title: Synopsis
sec.p: Α systematic method was first developed for capturing dynamic response of an important class of complex mechanical models. These models possess a large number of degrees of freedom, they are subjected to random excitation and involve strongly nonlinear characteristics. The success of this method was based on a substantial reduction of the order of the original model. This was achieved by applying a suitable coordinate condensation, so that the reduced model remains sufficiently accurate up to a level of forcing frequencies. This in turn facilitated the application of another method, leading to direct determination of steady-state response of dynamical models under periodic excitation. Combination of these methods with a rainflow cycle counting method led to an efficient methodology for predicting fatigue lifetime.

The methodology developed was applied to an involved finite element model of a city bus. Special emphasis was placed in determining several response quantities, related to fatigue performance, in a numerically efficient manner. Among other things, the results demonstrated that this methodology can be of valuable help in the efforts to predict the influence of parameters on the stochastic response and the fatigue life of large order nonlinear mechanical models in a systematic manner. Finally, the results obtained confirmed that the application of classical spectral methods can lead to quite accurate predictions when the model is linear. On the other hand, a critical assessment of the accuracy of these methods for nonlinear systems was also performed. It was found that their application to the nonlinear system examined can lead to severely non-conservative predictions of the fatigue lifetime.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research was partially supported by a grant from the General Secretariat of Research and Technology, Greek Ministry of Development and the European Union through the PENED 2003 program (03-ΕΔ-524).
